snippet: Officials saw James B. Comey’s remarks about the so-called Ferguson effect as undermining the administration’s criminal justice policies.

byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt reported from Washington, and Matt Apuzzo from Chicago.
byline.original: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MATT APUZZO

abstract: Justice Dept and White House officials criticize statement made by FBI Dir James B Coomey in which he said scrutiny of law enforcement has made police officers less aggressive, leading to rise in violent crime in some cities; holding police accountable for civil rights violations has been top priority in Obama administration, which sees remarks as undermining its signature efforts at criminal justice reform.
lead_paragraph: Officials saw James B. Comey’s remarks about the so-called Ferguson effect as undermining the administration’s criminal justice policies.

headline.print_headline: White House Disagrees With F.B.I. Chief on Scrutiny as a Cause of Crime
headline.main: White House Disagrees With F.B.I. Chief on Scrutiny as a Cause of Crime
